awd_titl_txt: Culturally Relevant Robotics: A Family and Teacher Partnership for Computational Thinking in Early Childhood
awd_abstract_narration:
Early and culturally relevant coding experiences nurture the computational thinking necessary for continued learning and interest in computer science. Developing interest in and support for computer science is important for participation in computer science degrees at the post-secondary level. This project has the potential to improve the teaching of computer science in early childhood by making explicit what needs to be known pedagogically about engaging Black and Latinx children in computational thinking. This study could shift the field to consider the unique needs of Black and Latinx children in computer science education from the beginning of formal schooling. The project also has the potential to prompt early childhood curricula to be attuned to STEM learners’ identities with respect to race and class. Finally, the project has the potential to improve the social well-being of Black and Latinx learners by equipping their parents and caretakers to support children as they envision themselves in STEM across PreK-16 education. 

The purpose of this medium research-practice-partnership project in the PreK-8 strand is to generate an actionable theory of change for promoting computational thinking and a sense of belonging in computer science through a culturally relevant robotics program  developed in partnership with university teacher educators and researchers, administrators, teachers, coaches, and Black and Latinx children and their families. This research practice partnership will study: (1) the iterative co-development and refinement of a classroom- and home-based culturally relevant robotic program for Black and Latinx preschoolers and (2) how Black and Latinx children develop understanding of computational thinking and a sense of belonging in computer science as they engage in a culturally relevant robotics program. The proposed project leverages and expands upon existing collaborations towards culturally relevant STEM education among University of Tennessee and school partners at two schools – a preschool with 163 children (90% Black) and a primary school (PreK-1) with 221 (63% Black, 24% Latinx) children. This project includes elements of both design-based research, by situating curricular interventions in authentic settings, and community-based participatory research where participants’ voices guide the design and direction of the program. The project spans four phases where community partnerships will be strengthened and extended, curriculum will be co-designed and piloted, program implementation will be adjusted based on ongoing data analysis, and full implementation will lead to theory building and program development for broader impact. In addition to presenting and publishing research findings, the investigators will develop short briefs that can be sent to the local school board, administrators, community leaders, and the state department of education. Their final actionable theory of change and models for a family-teacher partnership for culturally relevant robotics programs will be disseminated broadly on a website in order to provide free and easy access to other teacher educators, teachers, instructional coaches, families, and school and community leaders. 

This project is funded by the CS for All: Research and RPPs program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Culturally Relevant Robotics: A Family and Teacher (CRRAFT) Partnership was inspired by the need to develop culturally responsive computing education approaches specifically for young children who are members of groups underrepresented in computer science. Although educational technologies and curricula tailored to young children exist, models for culturally responsive computing education have been studied only among older children and students. Yet, a sense of belonging in STEM, including computer science, starts at an early age, thus diversifying the computer science workforce demands culturally responsive computing education among Black and Latinx preschoolers. The goals for the CRRAFT Partnership were: (1) to co-develop and refine a classroom- and home-based culturally relevant robotics program (CRR Program) for Black and Latinx preschoolers; and (2) to assess the impact of the CRR Program on children’s computational thinking and sense of belonging in computer science. 

Across multiple years, members of the CRRAFT Partnership included a university team of researchers and teacher educators, a district-wide instructional coach, teachers from across ten public, Title I preschools, and parent representatives from those schools. Through three cycles of design-based research, the partnership members iteratively co-designed, tested, and revised school- and home-based versions of the CRR Program. The first iteration of the program was implemented in the 2021-22 school year, and the final version was implemented in 2023-24. Overall, approximately 400 children, mostly from Black and Latinx families, engaged in the CRR Program during this time. 

The final version of the CRR Program included four phases, or curricular units, which highlighted a big idea in early computational thinking: (1) sequencing; (2) design process; (3) modularity; and (4) control structures. Each school-based phase included a focal experience centered on the big idea and four small group activities to help children prepare for the focal experience. Suggestions for incorporating culturally responsive computing into learning stations (i.e., areas of the classroom for play-based learning with puppets, blocks, etc.), and connections to children’s literature were also included. The final home-based CRR Program was reimagined as a technology library at a local children’s STEAM museum. Families from the schools can access the library to check out technology kits, which include guides (in English and Spanish) developed by CRRAFT partners on using the materials in culturally responsive, developmentally appropriate ways to highlight big ideas of early computational thinking.

Each year, the CRRAFT Partnership led multiple presentations at academic conferences and teacher development meetings, regularly including teacher and parent partners as presenters. Research yielded over ten peer-reviewed publications and one PhD dissertation (expected by August 2025). These studies examined partnership development, curriculum co-design and content analysis, and students’ computational thinking and sense of belonging. Results provide new knowledge for the field on the specific mechanisms needed to provide culturally relevant opportunities for computational thinking among preschoolers. Key findings included: (1) Teacher and parent partners conceptualized culturally relevant computing and made connections to familiar routines differently. Thus, involving parents as co-designers proved essential in ensuring cultural responsiveness; (2) Facilitators of partnerships involving parents and teachers require distinct approaches to team building, including intentional efforts to invite participation and revoice contributions; (3) Theories of culturally responsive computing developed through research with older children remained relevant in curricular co-design for young children, with some necessary adaptations. Most notably, adaptations to shift the focus away from digital tools to unplugged tools (i.e., coding activities done without a computer or robot) were needed to position preschoolers as innovators with technology and technosocial change agents in play-based ways; and (4) When teachers assess children’s computational thinking development, wide variability in measures of CT existed. Yet, analysis of researcher-developed CT measures showed significant increases in children’s CT from the beginning to the end of the school year in classrooms using the CRR Program.

The CRR Program is available freely through the project website, and has been viewed 4500 times since July 2021. As of April 2025, aspects of the school-based CRR Program are being used by teachers in at least three states (Tennessee, North Carolina and Texas), introducing approximately 350 children from groups underrepresented in computer science to culturally responsive computing education. Additionally, the home-based CRR Program is available through a children’s STEAM museum in East Tennessee, which serves over 100,000 children each year. For more information, visit: http://crraft.org.
